ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Column: 801

MONEY-LAUNDERING AND TERRORIST FINANCING ACTIVITIES

(Preventive measures)

    

     1.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Senior Minister whether there is any basis for the US State Department's allegation that Singapore is a major money-laundering country.

     2.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Senior Minister (a) whether there are sufficient safeguards to prevent money-laundering and terrorist financing activities;  and (b) how does the Monetary Authority of Singapore  ensure that banks fully comply with such measures.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) (for the Senior Minister, Prime Minister's Office):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together, please?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  The US State Department's International Narcotics Control Strategy Report for 2003, which was released on 1st March 2004, listed a range of jurisdictions as being of primary concern in respect of money laundering from international narcotics trafficking and other serious crimes.  Singapore was included in that list together with the UK, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Switzerland, as well as the US itself.  In short, all the major financial centres of the world were included in the  list.

 

   The US State Department Report did not provide any basis for suggesting that Singapore-based financial institutions engage in transactions involving a significant amount of proceeds from

Column: 802

international narcotics trafficking and other serious crimes. 

 

   However, money laundering must be a concern in every country, and especially in international financial centres which handle huge volumes of transactions on a daily basis. Singapore takes its responsibilities very seriously in this regard.  We are a member of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF), the international body that develops policies and standards to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.  The US State Department's Report indeed acknowledges that Singapore strongly opposes money laundering and terrorism financing and has been a key player in the regional effort to stop terrorist financing in Southeast Asia.

 

   MAS requires all banks and financial institutions operating in Singapore to institute rigorous measures to guard against money-laundering and terrorist financing.  These include the need to identify and know their customers and their customers' source of funds.  They also have  to maintain the records necessary to reconstruct and explain details of transactions, and to report all suspicious transactions.  MAS conducts both offsite reviews and onsite inspections of banks and financial institutions to ensure that these measures are in place.  External auditors engaged by banks and financial institutions are similarly required to audit for compliance with MAS regulations.   Through these rigorous processes, banks have identified and filed suspicious transaction reports with the Commercial Affairs Department CAD).  CAD investigates these reports and, where it finds wrongdoing, it will take firm action.

 

   In August 2003, Singapore completed its IMF/World Bank Financial Sector Assessment Programme.  The team of assessors found that Singapore has a comprehensive legal, institutional, policy and supervisory framework to combat

Column: 803

money laundering and terrorism financing.  They also noted that our financial institutions have a strong compliance culture for requirements to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.

 

   Singapore will stay fully committed to the international effort against money laundering and terrorist financing.  Our high regulatory and supervisory standards are recognised internationally. The integrity of our financial sector is a key asset which we intend to preserve.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, the Minister has given a comprehensive reply to the questions.  My question to the Minister is:  what else can be done in order to have Singapore removed from the list in view of the fact that we have put so many safeguards and measures in place and yet we have been cited in the report since 1987? 

 

    My second question is whether the US State Department has cited any specific incidence or evidence to support their allegation that we are a major money-laundering country because Singaporeans are obviously very concerned over this label and they would like to see it removed. 

 

    My third question is what other steps have been taken in order to try and make clear our position and make the US State Department understand our position, in particular, whether we have tried to enlist the help and get our Embassy in the US to speak to the US State Department or get the American Ambassador here to do so.

 

     My final question, Sir, is whether there has been an increase in the number of suspicious transactions reported by the banks and whether there has been any prosecution by the CAD arising from such reports.

Column: 804

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  I would like to thank Mdm Halimah for her useful questions.  What steps can we take?  It is really continuous work on the part of the banks to keep an eye out for anything that looks suspicious and to know their customers.  The provisions are there not just in name.  It is a real process where bank officers have to go through the full process of checking out the customers, trying to identify the source of funds and so on.  It is also something which MAS takes very seriously in all its inspections of banks.  It is a regular feature of the offsite review of information that is provided from the banks to the MAS, as well as the inspections we do when we go onsite to the banks themselves.  We look up their records, check some transactions, speak to them about their processes, and speak to the audit committee, and so on.  So it is something that we take very seriously.

 

     There were no specifics mentioned in the latest report to justify Singapore's inclusion among the jurisdictions suspected of being money-laundering centres.  But one can infer from the list of countries included that all the major financial centres, by virtue of the fact that they have a very large volume of transactions, including currency transactions, passing through their centres on a daily basis, both onshore and offshore, are vulnerable to money laundering.  We should not deny that.  As an international financial centre, we should take it all the more seriously and keep working at it.

 

     Yes, we will keep up with our communication with the US State Department.  I think they understand our position.  They themselves have recognised in their report that Singapore is in the forefront of the fight against money laundering and terrorism financing and we will keep our line of communication with them.

 

     Can Mdm Halimah please repeat her fourth question?

Column: 805

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  My fourth question is:  has there been an increase in the number of suspicious transactions?

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  Unfortunately, I do not have the data with me.  Reporting of suspicious transactions is a mandatory requirement under the law.  Failure to comply is a criminal offence.  So our banks take it very seriously.  You will see the number moving up and down from year to year.  I do not think we see an uptrend as such.  Yes, there have been prosecutions.  In fact, over the last three years alone, there have been more than 10 prosecutions by the CAD.

Column: 805

PRIME MINISTER'S VISIT TO MALAYSIA

(Update)

     3.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs (a) if he will update the House on the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance's recent visit to Malaysia; (b) what was the tipping point that led to the new wave of good tidings between the two Prime Ministers; and (c) how can it be ensured that the new relationship will be maintained for the mutual benefit of both countries.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr George Yong-Boon Yeo):  Mr Speaker, Sir, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made his introductory visit to Malaysia on 4-5th October 2004.  This was his second introductory visit to an ASEAN country to meet his counterparts.  Although brief, it was a good visit.

 

   Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi and the Malaysian government accorded Prime Minister Lee and the Singapore delegation a warm welcome.  Prime Minister Lee held a private, four-eye meeting with Prime Minister Abdullah, followed by a full delegation meeting.  The two Prime Ministers, who are also Finance Ministers, signed a new Double Taxation Agreement (DTA) which will eliminate double taxation

Column: 806

and promote cross-border investments.  Their discussions focused on the two countries working together to strengthen bilateral ties, and to develop new areas of win-win cooperation.  We already cooperate in a broad range of areas, including trade and investments, tourism, security as well as in handling problems like SARS and the avian flu. The Prime Ministers agreed that the two countries should enhance cooperation in areas such as tourism and transport links, including air transport. Our private sector should also do more.  Prime Minister Lee noted that the tone of bilateral relations had improved and that both sides had to "build on this and develop more momentum and cooperation".

 

   The two Prime Ministers also agreed that Singapore and Malaysia should look ahead, and not allow problems to affect overall cooperation. On the outstanding bilateral issues, Prime Minister Abdullah put forward some suggestions. Prime Minister Lee informed him that for continuity, he had asked Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong to handle these issues. Senior Minister Goh is familiar with the details and complexities of these issues, and will study carefully any Malaysian proposals. Prime Minister Abdullah reiterated his invitation for Senior Minister Goh to visit Malaysia soon, and we are working on possible dates for the visit.

 

   Relations between countries, particularly close partners like Singapore and Malaysia, are not driven by "tipping points" but rather by fundamental interests. In many areas, the fundamental interests of Malaysia and Singapore run parallel, and link us together. In the wider perspective, we are not each other's main competitors.

 

  Singapore and Malaysia now see an opportunity to take bilateral cooperation to a new level. Maintaining this momentum will require hard work on both

Column: 807

sides. From the way we cooperated to tackle problems such as terrorism and the Avian flu, there are grounds for optimism.

 

  But we must also be realistic. Apart from the outstanding bilateral issues, as two close neighbours, we must expect other disagreements and difficulties to arise from time to time. This is inherent in our situation. However, we must not allow these disagreements to define the entire bilateral relationship, or prevent cooperation in other areas. On this basis, I am confident that we will be able to improve our relationship in a mutually beneficial way.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I have three supplementary questions for the Minister.  One is that it was reported in the papers by Senior Minister that there is an indication by Mr Abdullah Badawi for an issue-by-issue negotiation of our outstanding issues.  I would like to ask the Minister whether there was this preferred indication in the past and, if not, why are we conceding to this request. 

      The second question would be:  with this shift in negotiation from a total package to an issue-by-issue approach, would there be an impact on the outcomes of our settlement and would it be against the interest of Singapore in any way?

      The third question would be:  how can we ensure that agreements reached between leaders would be kept in good faith subsequently?

     Mr George Yong-Boon Yeo:  Mr Speaker, Sir, as Members are aware, in the past we had talked about the package and the Malaysian side decided that they should abandon the package.   We suggested in that case that we let these issues be resolved separately, going to

Column: 808

third-party adjudication, if necessary.  But when Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi came down earlier this year, he suggested that we should take a fresh look.  At that time, Prime Minister Goh said that we were prepared to see what he proposed and we are still waiting for the Malaysians to propose ideas to us. 

    We keep an open mind on the issue-by-issue approach and I do not think we should, at this point in time, foreclose any possible solution or outcome.  Will this damage Singapore's national interest?  Obviously, when we negotiate we must negotiate in the interest of Singapore but try to find solutions which are win-win for both sides, and not see, as far as possible, problems or issues in a zero-sum way.

     On the question of both sides negotiating in good faith, obviously so.

Column: 808

MEDIA LIBERALISATION

     4.  Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts, given the recent merger deal between Singapore Press Holdings and MediaCorp, (a) what lessons can be drawn on the process of media liberalisation;  and (b) how can it be ensured that media competition in future can succeed and result in greater product variety and better-quality journalism.

     The Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (Dr Lee Boon Yang):  Mr Speaker, Sir, let me say from the outset that although we have given in-principle approval to Singapore Press Holdings and MediaCorp's application for merging part of their media operations, the Media Development Authority and my Ministry are in the process of examining the application and studying the details of the merger before taking a decision on formal approval.

 

     Having said that, Sir, I now turn to the lessons that we can draw from this

Column: 809

experience.  The aim of the media liberalisation in June 2000 was to help the local media diversify their media operations, tap the benefits of media convergence and give Singaporeans more choices in terms of TV and newspaper offerings.  This was also to prepare the local media for competition in an increasingly globalised economy.  As a result of media liberalisation, consumers, local production houses and advertisers have benefited from the increase in supply of media products.  Compared to pre-liberalisation, Singaporeans now enjoy a wider selection of TV programmes from two additional TV channels and additional free newspapers, namely TODAY and Streats. 

 

     Sir, while competition has brought about some benefits for consumers, it has also demonstrated the difficulties faced by Singapore Press Holdings and MediaCorp when they venture into each other's traditional preserves.  Competition reveals that a small media market, a limited talent pool and a small advertising pie segmented by languages are major constraints in the media environment.  These constraints were exacerbated by the onset of economic downturn post-liberalisation and the consequential shrinkage in advertisement spending by companies.  Furthermore, both companies resorted to aggressively bidding for imported content and undercutting each other's advertising rates.  It is therefore not surprising that they suffered substantial financial losses in the midst of an economic recession.  While we acknowledge that free-to-air TV services typically take several years before breaking even, we have to accept the companies' decision in not wanting to incur further losses.

 

     The experience of Singapore Press Holdings and MediaCorp illustrates the complexity in media competition.  Whilst competition may have worked well for other small countries, there is no one-size-fits-all formula for success as each

Column: 810

country is different.  Nevertheless, we have gained a better understanding of our media environment and a greater awareness of the challenges our media players face.  Our experience had helped us to draw up a media competition code which was introduced in April 2003 as "The Code of Practice for Market Conduct in the Provision of Mass Media Services".

 

    Sir, some have attributed the failure of both companies to the lack of a media competition code from the very beginning.  I do not share this view.  While the media competition code could guard against anti-competitive behaviour by preventing the dominant player from gaining unfair advantage over new entrants through predatory pricing, it could not be used to micro-manage the business strategy of media companies.  Thus, it would not have addressed the aggressive competition for viewers and readers adopted by the two media companies.  Such behaviour is best left to the market to sort out. 

 

     Sir, on the second question concerning media competition, the Government will not reverse its policy on media liberalisation and will remain committed to allowing competition.  We do not have a cap on the number of media licences.  Notwithstanding MediaCorp and Singapore Press Holdings' decision to merge, the Government continues to welcome new players willing to enter the TV and/or newspaper market, if they meet the prevailing criteria for such licences.

 

     However, I would like to reiterate that the Government cannot foster competition at all costs or ensure that every media operation entering the market will succeed.  Business success will depend on the operator's entrepreneurial capability and be subjected to the discipline of market forces.

 

     On the Government's part, we will continue to foster a healthy media

Column: 811

environment for the benefit of Singaporeans.  We will continue to encourage the media players to strive for excellence, whether in broadcasting or newspapers. Both companies have indicated that through pooling of resources, they will be able to enhance the quality of their respective products and reach out to the regional markets. We support this strategy which can result in better media products for Singaporeans. 

 

    Sir, let me assure the Member that in considering the proposed merger, the interests of Singaporeans, who are consumers of the media services, will not be disregarded.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  Supplementary question for a start, Sir. 

     Mr Speaker:  Supplementary questions will do.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:   Sir, can I take it that the Minister is saying that the failure of the two media companies to compete is because of their business strategy and not because of the regulatory environment?  As the Minister noted, a point which has been made is that the media competition "came very late" three years after the media was liberalised.

     Mr Speaker:  Ms Ng, no speeches, please.  Just ask your questions.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:  Whereas in the telecommunications industry, it came on in the same year.  Is the Minister aware that in the case of the telecommunications industry, it has succeeded in producing a better variety of service providers and products for consumers?

      Mr Speaker:  Ms Ng, what are your questions?

Column: 812

      Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:   Is the Minister aware that one reason why the telecommunications industry was successful in liberalising was because of the competition code that was introduced in the same year that it was liberalised?  That is my first question.  My second question is:  can I ask the Minister what he would like to see as a desired outcome as a result of media liberalisation, given the state of play now and the experience of the last three years?  And finally, can I ask the Minister whether he thinks that the merger deal, if approved, would send the signal to new players that this is indeed a hard game to play, that even media companies with deep pockets cannot sustain it? Will it mean that, in fact, the media industry will be hampered in terms of liberalisation?

     Mr Speaker:  I would like to remind Members to keep their questions short, please. We have so many Questions to deal with.  Dr Lee.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already explained in my main answer that I do not think we can attribute the failure of the broadcast and print media competition to the lack of a competition code or competition regulation right from the onset.  I think it is not fair to compare the broadcast and print media to the telecommunications market.  Both markets are quite distinctly different, involving different technology applications.  In the case of the failure of the broadcast and the print media competition, as I have explained, one of the significant factors is the shrinkage of the advertisement pie over the period from 2000 up to now.  When the media market was liberalised in 2000, the approximate broadcast advertisement expenditure was around $200 million and it was projected to increase yearly to a figure of $270 million.  But we know that, in reality, far from increasing, soon after liberalisation, the amount of expenditure spent for

Column: 813

advertisements actually fell, and last year it was only about $180 million.  So, instead of increasing, it actually fell.  To some extent, the competitors adopted strategies which further undermined each other's viability by way of a "cut-throat" type of competition that certainly did not help in business viability.  It is not a question of not having a competition code in place. 

 

    I would also like to remind the Member that in the case of telecommunications, the competition code came later after the market was thrown open for new entrants to the market.  It was about nine months or so before the competition code was introduced.  So one cannot take the approach that just because it was liberalised without an existing regulatory framework, it was doomed to failure.  I think the two businesses are quite different - newspaper broadcasting versus telecommunications.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, with the exception of one totally irrelevant speech from a Member who has totally disappeared, I would like to thank all the many Members of this House who have shared the benefits of their wisdom and experience and their thoughts on this piece of legislation.

Background

 

     Sir, I will start by introducing the background behind these changes.  The SAVER-Premium Fund was introduced to provide financial security for the SAF servicemen after their military careers. The SAVER-Premium Fund has two components: a Defined Benefits component, and a Defined Contributions component. The Defined Benefits component is the amount set aside primarily to service MINDEF's obligations to pay for the post-retirement medical benefits, also START benefits (which are lump-sum payments to Warrant Officers and Specialists on completion of 10 years of service) and compensations (arising

This Defined Contributions component is not affected by this Bill. It will continue to be managed and invested by MINDEF.

 

Rationale for transferring the DB component

 

     As such, the investment objectives of the Defined Benefits and Defined Contributions are different.  The adequacy of the Defined Benefits component depends on actuarial outcomes, like how many officers and servicemen will require medical benefits post-retirement.  On the other hand, beneficiaries of the Defined Contributions component participate fully in the risks and returns of the investments.  In other words, they take the ups and downs of such investments.
 
     MINDEF therefore intends to transfer the Defined Benefits component for central management within the Government Pension Fund. The transfer will allow the Defined Benefits component to be co-invested with the Pension Fund, which shares the same investment objective and has a larger risk pool. Furthermore, since both Funds - the State Pension Fund and the Defined Benefits Funds - are defined benefits in nature, the transfer can also result in better economy of scale in their management.

SYNTHETIC DRUGS

     16.   Ms Indranee Rajah asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what steps are being taken to combat the perception among young Singaporeans that synthetic drugs are merely "recreational drugs" and therefore harmless and non-addictive; and (b) whether there is a rehabilitation programme for users of synthetic drugs.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:

     Unlike those who abuse traditional drugs such as heroin, synthetic drug abusers often do not experience severe physical withdrawal symptoms. This, coupled with the fact that synthetic drugs are often abused at nightspots and rave parties, has led to the perception that synthetic drugs are harmless, non-addictive and can be used as a form of recreation.  Therefore, synthetic drug abusers, especially the young and impressionable, think that taking synthetic drugs is not really harmful, but is hip and cool.

 

     The Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) is aware of this.  Thus, CNB has organised many preventive drug education (PDE) activities targeting youths to highlight the danger of taking synthetic drugs. For example, CNB conducts talks, competitions, drama retreats and camps to highlight the harmful effects of synthetic drugs.  In addition, the National Council Against Drug Abuse (NCADA) and CNB have been organising the annual "Clubs Against Drugs" Campaign to enlist club operators to promote anti-drug messages to their patrons who are mainly young adults. NCADA also mounted a media campaign against ketamine abuse in March this year, targeting specifically youths.

 

     Many audio-visual materials such as videos, posters and pamphlets on synthetic drugs have also been distributed to schools. These include an animated video titled "The Way Out" which highlights the dangers of synthetic drugs such as ketamine, 'Ice' and 'Ecstasy'; a "Treading on Ice" video which describes the pain and suffering of three ex-'Ice' abusers caused to themselves and their loved ones, and a docu-drama entitled "Temptations" where local icons such as Zoe Tay and Stephanie Sun put across strong anti-drug messages.

 

     All these measures have borne fruit.  The number of synthetic drug abusers arrested dropped from 564 in the first half of last year to 314 in the first half of this year.  In particular, the number of young synthetic drug abusers arrested, ie, those below 20 years, declined sharply from 95 to 48.  CNB will continue to focus its PDE programmes on synthetic drugs to ensure that these drugs do not gain a foothold in Singapore, especially among our youths.

     1.   Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) if he will give a  breakdown of the migration figures for the last 10 years on (i) the number of Singaporeans who had emigrated and given up on their Singapore citizenship, (ii) the number of immigrants who have taken up Singapore citizenship, (iii) the age, qualification and employment profile of these migrants, (iv) the number of emigrants who are retired officers from Government service and Government-linked companies; and (b) whether his Ministry had any success in reducing the number of Singaporeans who had given up on their citizenship over this period.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:

     Between 1994 and 2003, an average of about 860 Singaporeans renounced their Singapore citizenship while about 8,100 foreigners became Singapore citizens annually.   The numbers have remained stable over the years.

 

     About 60% of our new Singaporeans are below 30 years old.   Roughly two-thirds of our new Singaporeans attained Singapore citizenship as they were family members of Singaporeans. The remaining one-third obtained Singapore citizenship on their own merit.

 

     In 2002 and 2003, about half of those who renounced their Singapore citizenship were between the ages of 21 and 40.   Only a third held a diploma or higher qualifications.   We do not keep data on renunciations dating back further than two years ago and the previous employment of Singaporeans who have given up their Singapore citizenship, including ex-citizens who are retired officers from Government service and Government-linked companies.

 

     The Government is also looking into ways to effectively engage overseas Singaporeans, and to maintain their connections with Singapore.

FIRE-RATED DOORS FOR HDB FLATS

     2.   Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will give a progress update on the installation of fire-rated doors for HDB flats within five metres from any staircase; (b) what is the number installed to date and the number awaiting installation; and (c) what is the scheduled list of blocks that are pending installation.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:

     HDB blocks constructed before 1993 were built according to prevailing building requirements.  Following the revision of the Fire Code, HDB embarked on a programme in 1994 to enhance the fire safety features in these blocks.

     The scope of works under the programme to improve fire safety include:

 

     (a) Provision of dry riser for fire fighting purpose;

 

     (b) Installation of a firemen's switch in at least one of the existing lifts; and

 

     (c) Replacement of main entrance door to fire-rated doors for flats within three metres of staircase and lift lobby.  This is to prevent fire in a flat from spreading to the fire escape route and to ensure that the lift lobby and staircase are well protected so that all residents in the block can evacuate safely in the event of a fire.

HEALTH PROMOTION BOARD

     3.   Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Minister for Health what is the role of the Health Promotion Board with regard to enhancing education of  the public on their health.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:

     The Health Promotion Board (HPB) is the lead agency for national health promotion, health education and disease prevention.  It carries out health education and promotes healthy lifestyles to the general population. 

 

     HPB conceptualises, develops and implements health promotion programmes that reach out to specific sectors of the population.  Programmes for children include health education, myopia prevention, health screening and immunisation and provision of basic dental services in schools.  Programmes for the adults and elderly include the National Healthy Lifestyle Programme, National Smoking Control Programme, Nutrition Programme, Workplace Health Promotion Programme, Mental Health Education Programme, Community Health Screening and Breast and Cervical Cancer Screening Programmes.  Details of these programmes can be found at the HPB website (www.hpb.gov.sg).  Many of these programmes are expanded to target specific high risk groups to improve their effectiveness and health outcomes.

 

     HPB cannot do this alone.  It collaborates with many partners in the public, private and people sectors as well as grassroots organisations to effectively reach out to the target groups.  HPB also works closely with the media to provide the public with the necessary information and skills to adopt healthy practices and be more aware of matters related to their health.

TRAINING PROGRAMMES

     5.   Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Minister for Manpower, in the last year, what is the number of women and men in the age groups of 40 to 49, 50 to 59, 60 to 69, who have undergone re-training to make them more employable for the job market.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:

     The Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) captures trainee data for those above or below 40 years of age, but not by detailed breakdown into age bands.  Gender breakdown is available but only for some programmes.

 

     36% of 637,000 overall training places that WDA supported in 2003 were for workers aged 40 and above.   Specific programmes like the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP), which re-skills lower-skilled workers, supported the training of 46,155 workers of which 17,980 or 39% were aged 40 years and above.   Similarly in 2003, 41% of the participants in WDA's Place and Train Programmes where workers are trained for jobs found were aged 40 and above.

FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE

     6.   Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports if he will give the number of families and spouses, where the mother/wife is a former domestic worker or work permit holder, who have sought financial assistance over the last three years.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:

     Like any Singaporean family, a family where the mother or wife is a former foreign domestic worker or work permit holder may approach the Government for financial assistance if they are in need.

 

     The Government will assess requests for financial assistance based on the current and anticipated needs and circumstances of the Singapore family.   We would not consider the previous nationality or occupation of the family members in making an assessment.   As such, we do not track the number of families, where the mother or wife is a former foreign domestic worker or work permit holder, that have sought financial assistance.
